title: Ole Gunnar Solskjaer discusses Paul Pogba's future after Zinedine Zidane meeting
text:
The video will start in 8 Cancel

Get the biggest football stories by email Subscribe Thank you for subscribing We have more newsletters Show me See our privacy notice Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email

Manchester United boss Ole Gunnar Solskjaer insists he has no problem with Paul Pogba meeting Zinedine Zidane in Dubai.

The French midfielder was in the Middle East during the international break rehabbing the ankle injury that will keep him out of this weekend’s clash with Liverpool at Old Trafford.

And, as exclusively revealed by Mirror Sport, he ran into Real Madrid boss Zidane, who wanted to sign the £89million star in the summer.

However, United had no intention of selling, while Zidane couldn’t persuade president Florentino Perez to splash over £150million to take him to the Santiago Bernabeu.

Pogba and Zidane - both World Cup winners with France - chatted by a pool in Dubai after meeting up.

(Image: Daily Mirror)

Zidane was in the Middle East speaking at a conference relating to the integration of Artificial Intelligence in the sports industry.

Asked about Pogba and the pictures at his press conference on Friday, Solskjaer declared: "I don’t have any problem with that at all.”

(Image: 2019 Manchester United FC)

The Norwegian, backed this week by chief executive Ed Woodward, also insisted: "Paul is part of our plan.

"And I've spoken to Paul so many times. He’s been playing through the pain barrier and has been criticised left, right and centre.

"But when he came back, against Rochdale, Arsenal he could easily have opted not to play.

"He wanted to play, to try to get back. But it was too painful.

(Image: Getty Images)

“[Now] he’s on the way back, he’s recovering, he’s mending, he’s been on a few days off working but he’s away from here.

"And it’s a picture. When you’re at Man United [it happens]. You do get pictures, speculation.

"I don’t have any problem with it at all."

Pogba still has two years left on his Old Trafford deal, with a year's option in United's favour also.

However, if United can't mount an unlikely Champions League push this term, then he is unlikely to want to remain at the club in 2020.
description: Ole Gunner Solskjaer insists he has no problem with Pogba and that the Frenchman remains part of his long-term plan
